turns.speaker: ANNA
turns.text: Where've you been?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: What the fuck did you do with my stuff?

turns.speaker: ANNA
turns.text: Don't use language with me --

turns.speaker: ANNA
turns.text: Um, Erin?  Listen.  Even though you're not necessarily my favorite person in the world ...  ... sometimes you're not half-bad.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: I'm gonna assume that was meant as a compliment, Anna, and just say thank you.

turns.speaker: BAUM
turns.text: In terms of land value out in Hinkley, Mr. Masry, we feel it's a more than fair price.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: What about in terms of medical expenses? 250,000 doesn't come close to what this family's gonna have to spend on doctors.

turns.speaker: BAUM
turns.text: I understand they've had a bad run of luck, health-wise, and they have my sympathies. But that's not PG&E's fault.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: You're kidding, right?  Look at these readings for Christ's sake. PG&E's own technicians documented toxic levels of hexavalent chromium in those test wells, on numerous occasions.

turns.speaker: BAUM
turns.text: A million things could have caused those problems.  Poor diet, bad genes, irresponsible lifestyle.  Our offer is final and more than fair.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Wait a minute -- I thought we were negotiating here.

turns.speaker: BAUM
turns.text: 250,000 is all I'm authorized to offer.

turns.speaker: BAUM
turns.text: Mr. Masry, before you go off on some crusade, you might want to remember who it is you're dealing with here.  PG&E is a 28- billion dollar corporation.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Thanks.  I'll keep it in mind.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Tell you what, why don't you go on over to reception, tell them I said Mario should take you to the airport.

turns.speaker: BAUM
turns.text: Hey, excellent.  Thanks.

turns.speaker: BRENDA
turns.text: Tony Marvin.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Oh, Jesus.  Who's responsible for his pain and suffering this time?

turns.speaker: BRENDA
turns.text: His dry cleaners.  You want him?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: What do you think?  What's this?

turns.speaker: BRENDA
turns.text: Tequila.  From your drug dealer friend.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Carlos isn't a friend; he's a client.

turns.speaker: BRENDA
turns.text: He's a low-life.  Speaking of which, that's your nine o'clock in there.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Whoa.  Remind me.

turns.speaker: BRENDA
turns.text: Erin Brockovich.  Car accident.  Not her fault, she says.  And she looks like such an honest girl, don't you think?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: You shouldn't judge, Brenda.

turns.speaker: BRENDA
turns.text: Right.  Lap-dancers are people too.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: What the hell is this doing here?

turns.speaker: BRENDA
turns.text: It's those files you asked for.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: I didn't mean for you to leave them in the middle of the floor.  Jesus.  Look at me. What do I have this afternoon?

turns.speaker: BRENDA
turns.text: Nothing you can't show up for with a stain.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: What's she doing here?

turns.speaker: BRENDA
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Fax these to this number, okay?

turns.speaker: BRENDA
turns.text: All of 'em?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: All of them.

turns.speaker: DEFENDING LAWYER
turns.text: Seventeen thousand in debt.  Whew.  Is your ex-husband helping out?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Which one?

turns.speaker: DEFENDING LAWYER
turns.text: There's more than one?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Yeah.  There's two.  Why?

turns.speaker: DEFENDING LAWYER
turns.text: So.  You must've been feeling pretty desperate that afternoon.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: What's your point?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: What?  Hey -- <u>he</u> hit <u>me</u>.

turns.speaker: DEFENDING LAWYER
turns.text: So you say.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: He came tearing around the corner, out of control --

turns.speaker: DEFENDING LAWYER
turns.text: An ER doctor who spends his days saving lives was the one out of control --

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: That asshole smashed in my fucking neck!

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Meningitis?  What the hell is meningitis?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: It's an inflammation of the spinal cord and part of the brain.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Jesus.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: She must be a tough cookie, cause it's a pretty advanced case.  I'd say she's been walking around with it for a few weeks now.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: How does someone get meningitis?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Usually, in adults, it's from exposure to bacteria or a virus or ...

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: ... or lemme guess -- toxic waste?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Hi.  Donna Irving?

turns.speaker: DONNA
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: I'm Erin Brockovich, from Masry & Vititoe?

turns.speaker: DONNA
turns.text: You're a lawyer?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Hell, no.  I hate lawyers.  I just work for them.  You got a minute?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: This is a real nice place you got here.

turns.speaker: DONNA
turns.text: Well it oughta be, with all the work I put into it.

turns.speaker: DONNA
turns.text: I added air conditioning, put in the pool, made all those pillows by hand ...

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Yeah?  I should learn to do stuff like that. They make the place feel real homey.

turns.speaker: DONNA
turns.text: Thank you.  I think so too.  That's why I'm being such a stickler on this house price thing.  I don't mean to be a pain in PG&E's backside, especially after all they've done for Hinkley, but I look around here and I think, if they want this place, they're gonna have to pay for it.  And I don't just mean pay for the house; I'd like them to pay me for the trouble of starting over.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: DONNA
turns.text: Cause first you gotta move, then there's decorating, and if the windows aren't the same size, you know -- you're making all new curtains.  Honest to God, I don't know if I have the energy.  You know, I've been sick. Me and Peter both have.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Yeah, I'm real glad you brought that up.  I was going through your file here, and I ran into these medical records.  They kinda surprised me --

turns.speaker: DONNA
turns.text: I know.  They're more than a bit unusual. See, two years ago, Pete got Hodgkin's disease.  That's a kind of cancer --

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Yeah, I'm real sorry to hear that.

turns.speaker: DONNA
turns.text: Thank you.  It's in remission now, thank the Lord, but you never know.  And then while that's going on, I end up having to have a hysterectomy.  Plus a whole mess of lumps removed from my breasts.  All benign so far, but still, no matter how positive you stay, an operation can still take it out of you.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: I'll say.  Holy moley.

turns.speaker: DONNA
turns.text: So the whole idea of selling the house -- don't get me wrong, I'd be glad to move to some better place, but if they aren't gonna pay us properly, I just don't see the point.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Yeah, I can see that.  I guess the only thing that confused me is - - not that your medical problems aren't important, but -- how come the files about them are in with all the real estate stuff?

turns.speaker: DONNA
turns.text: Are you kidding?  With how our lives are, if I start subdividing files, I'll be sunk.  I just kept all PG&E correspondence in one place.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Right, but -- I'm sorry, I don't see why you were corresponding with PG&E about it in the first place.

turns.speaker: DONNA
turns.text: Well, they paid for the doctor's visit.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: They did?

turns.speaker: DONNA
turns.text: You bet.  Paid for a check-up for the whole family.  And not like with insurance where you pay, then wait a year to be reimbursed, either.  They just took care of it.  Just like that.  We never even saw a bill.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Wow.  Why would they do that?

turns.speaker: DONNA
turns.text: Cause of the chromium.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: The what?

turns.speaker: DONNA
turns.text: The chromium.  Well, that's what kicked this whole thing off.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: What's chromium?

turns.speaker: DONNA
turns.text: It's a chemical they used over at that compressor station up the road there.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Well, hell, maybe that's why you all have been so sick --

turns.speaker: DONNA
turns.text: I thought the same thing, right off the bat. That's why we went to see the doctor.  But hunh-uh.  Turns out one's got nothing to do with the other.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Seems like an awful big coincidence -- your water being messed with and you being so sick.

turns.speaker: DONNA
turns.text: Not around here.  This is a rough part of the world.  Hard times, not a lot of money, not a lot of luck.  It's a challenge, staying healthy in a town like this.  Heck, even our dogs up and die.

turns.speaker: DONNA
turns.text: An on-site monitoring well?  That means --

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: It was right up on the PG&E property over there.

turns.speaker: DONNA
turns.text: And you say this stuff, this hexavalent chromium -- it's poisonous?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: DONNA
turns.text: Well -- then it's gotta be a different than what's in our water, cause ours is okay. The guys from PG&E told me.  They sat right in the kitchen and said it was fine.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: I know.  But the toxicologist I been talking to?  He gave me a list of problems that can come from hexavalent chromium exposure. And everything you all have is on that list.

turns.speaker: DONNA
turns.text: No.  Hunh-uh, see, that's not what the doctor said.  He said one's got absolutely nothing to do with the other.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Right, but -- didn't you say he was paid by PG&E?

turns.speaker: DONNA
turns.text: Sure wish I had longer to get used to the idea.  You think if you got no uterus, and no breasts, you're still technically a woman?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Sure you are.  You're just a happier woman, cause you don't have to deal with maxi-pads and underwire.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: You wouldn't happen to have a little time right now, would you, Donna?

turns.speaker: DONNA
turns.text: For what?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Well, I was gonna head over to the Browns now.  I was thinking -- Mandy really values your opinion ...

turns.speaker: DONNA
turns.text: It's a good day.  I feel good.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Well, then -- if you're feeling up to it, maybe we should talk shop.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: The judge came up with a number.

turns.speaker: DONNA
turns.text: A number for the whole group, or for us?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Both.

turns.speaker: DONNA
turns.text: Oh, my God.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: And he's making them give five million of it to you all.

turns.speaker: DONNA
turns.text: Five million dollars?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Five million dollars.

turns.speaker: DONNA
turns.text: I don't even know how much money that is.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: It's enough -- for whatever you need, for whatever your girls need, for whatever your girls' girls need -- it'll be enough.

turns.speaker: DONNA
turns.text: I can put them in a good school.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Any school you want.

turns.speaker: DONNA
turns.text: And get someone to help around the house.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Yup.

turns.speaker: DONNA
turns.text: Oh my God.  Oh my God.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: They took some bone from my hip and put it in my neck.  I didn't have insurance, so I'm about seventeen thousand in debt right now.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: ... couldn't take painkillers cause they made me too groggy to take care of my kids.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: ... Matthew's six, Katie's four, and Beth's just nine months.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: ... just wanna be a good mom, a nice person, a decent citizen.  Just wanna take good care of my kids.  You know?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Yeah.  I know.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Open and shut?  <u>Open and fucking shut</u>?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: If you hadn't used profanity --

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Oh, please, it was long over by then.  God damn, he made me look like some cheap --

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: I told you the questions might get a little personal --

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Bullshit.  You told me I'd get half a million dollars.  You told me I'd be set.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Okay -- let's try and settle down here.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: <u>Settle down</u>?  I got 74 bucks to my name, Mr. Masry!  I can't <u>afford</u> to settle down!

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: I'm sorry, Erin.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Yeah?  Well, fuck you.  Sorry doesn't feed my kids.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: You never called me back.  I left messages.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: You did?  Wow, sorry about that.  Listen, Mario's a little not so bright.  He seems to think that you said --

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: There's two things I can't stand, Mr. Masry. Being ignored, and being lied to.  You did both.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: I never lied.  I may have miscalculated -- that happens sometimes, but --

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: You said things would be fine, and they're not.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: I'm sorry about that.  Really.  But --

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: I don't need pity.  I need a paycheck.  And I've looked, but when you've spent the last six years raising babies, it's real hard to convince someone to give you a job that pays worth a damn.  So I figure, since you're the one who said I was gonna be okay, you should be the one to hire me.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Okay, look.  If you really want to apply for a job here, you can do it the way everyone else does.  Send in a rÈsumÈ, make an --

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: I'm <u>not</u> everyone else, Mr. Masry.  I'm someone you made promises to that you didn't deliver on.  I trusted you.  With my kids' well-being.  Now, I'm smart, and I'm hard- working, and I'll do anything.  But if you think I'm leaving here without a job, you got another thing coming.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: I was wondering -- could you tell me who I'd talk to about maybe getting an advance on my paycheck?  Just -- for the weekend.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Jane's the office manager.  She handles payroll and petty cash.  But she leaves early on Fridays.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Oh.  Okay.  That's okay.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: All I have is hundreds.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: I don't wanna take your money, Mr. Masry.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Bullshit, you don't.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Give her a cold washcloth to suck on --  I gotta go -- there's a clean one in that bag -- I'll check back in a bit.  Sorry.  My kid --

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Where's Anna?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Out to lunch with the girls.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Oh.  Huh.  Well, look, I got this file I need valued. Real estate thing.  A lady has some property next to a PG&E plant that PG&E wants to buy. I need to know what to ask for it.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: You do know how to do that, don't you?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Yeah.  I got it.  No problem.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Good.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: You're a girl.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Excuse me?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: How come you're not at lunch with the girls? You're a girl.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: I guess I'm not the right kind.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Erin, you've been gone for a week.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: I left a message.  I've been dealing with that real estate thing.  I was gonna write up a whole damn report and --

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: That's not how we work here.  You don't just leave a message and take off.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Okay, enough --  Now, look, Erin -- this incident aside, I don't think this is the right place for you. So what I'm gonna do is make a few calls on your behalf.  Find you something else, okay?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Don't bother.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Come on, I'm trying to help here.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Bullshit.  You're trying to feel less guilty about firing someone with three kids to feed.  Fuck if I'll help you do that.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: What are you doing here?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: I got an interesting call this afternoon. It was from a Dr. Frankel.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Oh, yeah?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: He wanted you to know the legal limit for hexavalent chromium, is .05 parts per million.  And that at the rate you mentioned, .58, it could be responsible for the cancers in that family you asked about. The Irvings.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Well, that was nice of him.  Isn't it funny how some people go out of their way to help people and others just give 'em the ax?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Look, I'm sorry.  You were gone.  I just assumed you were off having fun.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Now, why in the hell would you assume that?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: I don't know.  Maybe cause you look like someone who has a lot of fun.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Boy, are you ever a shitty judge of people.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: So what's the story on this thing?  This cancer stuff?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: You wanna know, you gotta hire me back.  I got a lot of bills to pay.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: But, PG&E told her about the chromium?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: They told her something, but it can't have been too specific, cause I talked to her, and she sure didn't think her water was bad.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: So what made you think it was?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: It doesn't take a genius to look at those medical records and think something's wrong.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: What medical records?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: The ones in the box of files.  The box of files?  The one from your office?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: I didn't see any medical records in there.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Boy, you musta really fine-tooth-combed it then, huh?  And <u>you</u> fired <u>me</u>.  Jesus.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: That document you found, the one that says it was the bad chromium -- you didn't happen to make a copy did you?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Course I did.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Lemme see it, will you?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: I want a raise.  And benefits.  Including dental.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Look, Erin, this is not the way I do business, this extortion nonsense.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Okay.  A 5% raise, and --

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Ten.  There's a lot of other places I could work.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: A ten percent raise and benefits.  But that's it.  I'm drawing the line.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: This is the only thing you found?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: So far.  But that place is a pig sty.  I wouldn't be surprised if there's more.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Find out.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: I'm telling you, the minute Brenda sent the fax -- I'm talking the second she pressed that send button -- PG&E claims department is on the phone to me, scheduling a meeting.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: So you think we got 'em scared?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: It sure as hell sounded like they were sitting up and taking notice.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: At least they made an offer.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: That wasn't an offer.  A million would've been an offer.  When they send the God damn mail clerk down to jerk me off, waste my time, it's a fuck you.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: I don't get why they'd do that.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Because they can.  You heard that kid -- they have 28 billion dollars at their disposal.  They can afford to waste all the time in the world.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: And you can't?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: What, you think I'm made of money?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Mr. Masry, Mario gets lost going to the bathroom.  They'll be driving around the valley for hours.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Yeah.  Isn't that a shame?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Boy, do I know how you feel.  First time I heard that number, I said you got to be kidding me.  Forty God damn percent?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Erin --

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: I'm the one who's injured, and this joker who sits at a desk all day is gonna walk away with almost half my reward?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Erin --

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Then I don't get anything either.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: And I realized, he's taking a chance too.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Hunh-uh.  Absolutely not.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: That's crazy -- why not?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Because I said no.  Look -- the only reason PG&E's even talking to us is cause this is a quiet little real estate dispute.  We add plaintiffs, and suddenly we're in the middle of a toxic tort -- with a statute problem -- against a massive utility.  No, thank you.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Okay, so here's what I'll do.  I'll go on up to Ted and Rita Daniels -- two of the nicest people you'd ever hope to meet, who spend every single day watching their little girl fight like a dog against this cancer -- I'll tell them we can't help them cause you don't feel like working that hard.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: It's not about working hard --

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Bullshit.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: -- It's about being realistic.  Something like this, Erin -- it could take forever. They're a huge corporation.  They'd completely bury us in paperwork.  I'm just one guy with a shitty little P.I. firm.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: -- who happens to know they poisoned people and lied about it.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: And this shit is bad news, Mr. Masry.  Not only does it attack every organ of the body, it fucks with your DNA, too.  That means these people's genes, and the genes of their kids, and the genes of their grandkids --

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: I know how DNA works, Erin --

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: We can get these people.  With a little effort, I really think we can nail their asses to the wall.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Oh, you do?  With all your legal expertise, you believe that?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Okay, fine.  I don't know shit about shit. But I know the difference --

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: How many families we talking about here?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Four more.  Eleven people.  So far.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: You think there's more?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Well -- I found one document at the water board that had a toxic test well reading from 1967.  A hell of a lot of people have lived on that land since then.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: This is a whole different ball game, Erin. A much bigger deal.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Kinda like David and what's-his-name?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Kinda like David and what's-his-name's whole fucking family.  Okay, here's the deal -- if, and only if, you find me the evidence to back all this up -- I'll do it.  I'll take it on.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: You're doing the right thing, Mr. Masry.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Yeah, yeah.  Remind me of that when I'm filing for bankruptcy.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: What now?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Another raise wouldn't hurt.  And with all the time I'm gonna be spending on the road, I'll probably be needing my own cel phone, won't I?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Is that what I think it is?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: She lived on the plume.  You never know.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: You wanna talk about --

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: <u>No</u>.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: They used the hex chrom here, in these cooling tanks, as an anti-corrosive.  Then they dumped it here, in these six ponds.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: I don't remember seeing any ponds up there.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: They covered 'em over.  And not too carefully either, cause you dig one inch under the surface, and the dirt is green as a fucking shamrock.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: And that's what caused the contamination?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: It didn't help, but no.  The real problem's on the bottom.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: See, according to this, they were supposed to line the ponds so this shit couldn't seep into the ground.  But guess what --

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: They skipped that step.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: I guess it was a little too inconvenient. So for fourteen years, this stuff flowed into the groundwater, free as you please.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Jesus.  I don't even wanna ask what you did to make this Melendez guy talk.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: For your information, Frank cares what was in those ponds 'cause he used to spend half his day wading around them.  That was his job.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: No shit.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: No --

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Erin -- lemme tell you something.  If I'da put three researchers on this, I wouldn't expect them to dig up all the information you got here.  This is some damn good work.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Yeah?  Then gimme another raise.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Hey, I got a staff to pay, plus rent, plus I haven't billed a minute of my time since I started on this case, so you can quit hitting me up like I'm rich or something.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Don't give me that.  You're gonna get plenty rich off of this, Mr. 40 percent.  We got those PG&E fuckers by the balls here.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: We've got the PG&E fuckers in Hinkley by the balls.  But nobody's getting rich unless we can pin this on the corporate PG&E fuckers in San Francisco.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: PG&E corporate is claiming they had no way of knowing what was going on in Hinkley.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Oh, they knew.  They had to know.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Show me the document that proves that.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Then they didn't know.  And if they didn't know, we can't hit 'em for punitive damages. And punitive damages is where the money is.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Jesus Christ, Ed -- you know, the more I work on this thing, the more I realize what a crock of shit this legal system is.  Here we got a company that poisoned a whole aquifer -- that built a pool for a town, then filled it with toxic water -- and <u>we're</u> the ones who've gotta bust our ass proving things?  That's just not right.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: I like this case.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Really?  It makes me sick.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Me too.  That's why I like it.  It's been a long time since I had a case I cared about.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: You didn't care about my case?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: I would now.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Hey.  I like working with you.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Well, good, Ed.  I like working with you too.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: If they've sent that little shmuck Baum again, I'm gonna be real pissed off.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: From their tone of voice on the phone, I'd say they're taking us more seriously.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Yeah, I heard that one before.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Jesus.  They look like the Secret Service.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: They're trying to intimidate us.  Tell them to wait in the conference room.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Hey.  A new plaintiff called, wants to meet you.  I told him we'd be out there Thursday.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: D'you get his name?  Course not.  Jesus, Ed --

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: He said he'd be at the gas station at six.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Boy, this job takes me to some of the best damn places, huh?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Someone's following me.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: What?  Who?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Some guy in a truck -- he waited till I was alone, then he followed me, like, two miles. Jesus, I'm shaking.  Get me a beer.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: What kind of truck?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: I don't know.  Big.  Dark.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: He's gone.  Did you get a license plate?  Or a make?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: No, Ed -- what with me running for my life, I didn't have time to check those things --

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: I was just asking.  Are you all right?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Yeah.  Yeah, I'm ... fine.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: I want my fucking money --

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: I'm sorry, I'm gonna have to put you on hold for just one second here --  Do you mind?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Yeah, I mind.  You bet your ass I mind.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Oh, Jesus.  You wanna tell me what the problem is here, or --

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: It's my paycheck.  Which I earned.  Which I deserve.  Which I shouldn't have to beg for. That fat-ass bitch won't give it to me.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Erin, you're a big girl.  If you got a problem with Jane, work it out for yourself. I don't have time to deal with --

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Fuck you.  Make time.  Cause I bust my ass for you.  I watch everything else in my life go straight in the toilet, for you.  And what do you do for me?  Huh?  You see the way I'm treated around here -- but have you ever stood up for me once?  Have you ever mentioned to everyone what good work I'm doing?  Have you ever bothered saying, hey, Erin doesn't get paid the most cause she has the best tits; she gets paid the most cause she's the best God damn employee I've ever had?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Is that what you want?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: I want my paycheck.  By the end of the day.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: I'll see what I can do.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: You might want to think real hard about the amount, too.  My kids are sitting in the God damn parking lot right now, cause I still don't make enough to afford good child care. Makes me think about looking around for a job where I'm appreciated, for shit's sake.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: What kind of things come up?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Things like the head counsel for PG&E calling me with an offer.  20 million, plus attorney's fees.  Take it or leave it.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Whoa.  No shit.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: It's about 50 thousand per plaintiff.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: So what are you thinking?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: I'm thinking ... I wish someone else had to make this decision.  50 thousand bucks is more than any other California toxic plaintiff has gotten. Ever.  But ...

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: ... but it won't cover Annabelle Daniels's medical bills.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: And it's less than pocket change for PG&E.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Do you think we'd do better by going to trial?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Maybe.  but maybe not.  We still don't have anything linking this to PG&E corporate. Plus, there's the statute problem.  Plus, we're way short on manpower, so we'd need to bring on more lawyers ...

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Plus, 40 percent of 20 million's a whole lot of money.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: It's eight million dollars, Erin.  Eight million dollars.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Holy shit.  Who do they represent, God?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Don't joke.  They might.  So do me a favor and behave yourself for once.  Ed Masry to see Kurt Potter.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: What's a demur?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: It's PG&E saying to the judge that we don't have a case.  Their lawyers go --

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Counts?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Reasons PG&E thinks it shouldn't go to --

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Why good?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: He's got a reputation for doing all his --

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: She insulted me!

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Bullshit.  It was a misunderstanding.  But instead of handling it politely, instead of treating her with respect --

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Why the fuck should I respect her?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Because <u>that's how people treat each other</u>!

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Not in my world.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Gee, I wonder why.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: If you tell me to relax, I'm gonna kick your fucking head off --

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Erin, it's just a meeting.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: People don't fly down in their own god damn plane for "just a meeting" --

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Look, you said you weren't feeling great.  I thought you should rest.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Bullshit.  You'd drag me off my deathbed if it suited you.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Okay, look.  It's an important meeting. Kurt thought, if it was just lawyers --

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Kurt thought?  What about you?  Do you think anymore?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Look, this is serious now.  They're talking serious money --

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: And, what, I'm not serious?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: You're emotional.  You're erratic.  You say any God damn thing that comes into your head.  And I'm not saying that's bad.  That can be great; that can be a lot of fun --

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: "Fun?"  Jesus, "<u>fun</u>?"  I kill myself for a year and a half, hand you the best case of your life on a God damn silver platter, remind you of why you became a lawyer in the first place, and you think of me as "fun?"

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Okay, now you're making this personal, and it isn't --

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: <u>Not personal</u>?  That's my <u>work</u> in there, Ed. My sweat, my labor, my time.  If that's not personal, I don't know what is.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: How dare you take that away from me.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: No one's taking anything --

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Bullshit.  You stuck me in Siberia dictating to some God damn steno clerk so you could finish this thing without me.  After all I've done for you, that's the thanks I get.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Don't give me that.  You've gotten plenty. You've been well-paid; you've gotten lots of perks ...

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Perks?  Jesus -- <u>perks</u>?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: If you're here to fire me, your timing's lousy.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: I'm not gonna fire you.  I wanted to.  But then you got sick, and that woulda made me look like a shit.  You embarrassed me, Erin.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: I know.  I'm sorry.  Do I get to hear what happened anyway?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Between 50 and 400 million, definitely?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Uh-huh.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: And if you had to guess ...

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: With nothing linking it to the corporate offices yet, I'd say we'll end up on the lower end of that.  Still a lot of money.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: So why would PG&E offer it?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Because.  They know the evidence; they know they're gonna lose a jury trial.  Maybe they wouldn't lose 400 million bucks, but once you factor in all they'd spend on this case in the next ten years, it makes a lot of --

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Wait, what do you mean, ten years?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Five years, maybe, for a trial.  Double that for the appeal.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: I'm sorry, are you saying that if this thing goes to trial, it'll be <u>ten years</u> before these plaintiffs see their money?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Hey, that's not so bad.  Compare it to the Love Canal -- that was twenty years ago, and those people still haven't seen a dime.  So in legal terms, ten years is --

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Fuck legal terms.  We're talking about human beings here.  Sick people.  A whole bunch of them are gonna be dead in ten years.  They need their money now!  We gotta get 'em to agree to the arbitration, Ed.  We gotta get every damn one of those plaintiffs to --

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: <u>I know</u>.  We're having a meeting, it's all set up --

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: When?  Where?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Tuesday at seven, at the Hinkley firehouse.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Okay, good.  I think I should be the one to tell 'em, cause they trust me more than --

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: You're not gonna be there.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: The fuck I'm not.  I don't care what the doctor says --

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: This isn't doctor's orders.  It's mine.  I'm saying you can't come.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Because Kurt doesn't want to work with you. He thinks you're a loose cannon.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Fuck Kurt.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Erin --

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: No, I'm serious.  You know what Kurt Potter is?  He's the kind of guy who never would have taken this case in the first place. He's the kind of guy who would have sold these plaintiffs down the river when PG&E offered 20 million.  He doesn't work like us, Ed.  There's no little voice in his head telling him to do the right thing.
